text:
Alex Scott: What’s your first impression
of the building?
Andrew Cornwall: It’s big.

Scott: London’s brand new Francis Crick
Institute opened in fall 2016 with hopes that

its impressive, expansive design would attract
brilliant biomedical scientists.

Now the Crick has opened its doors to the
public to communicate the importance of the

research going on there, with help from audiovisual
exhibits.

We visited the Crick to see how it was faring,
which is how we met Andrew Cornwall, an environmental

archeologist, who we asked about the institute's
outreach effort.

Cornwall: It’s important to communicate
all science with the public.

We’re scientifically illiterate, I think,
as a community now and it’s important that

we engage everyone and what better way to
engage people than with wonderful visual effects
like this.
Scott: Roxie Esterle agrees.

She’s a science teacher from Los Angeles
that we met at the Crick, and a science teacher
who’s also met Francis Crick.

Esterle: I think it’s fantastic having an
exhibition open to the public because these

are things that are normally only seen by
scientists.

And being able to see things in action, such
as blood clotting or the HeLa cells growing,

[is] very exciting and very important for
the public to see.

Scott: The building clearly appeals to people
with a predilection for science—including
the scientists working there.

John Williamson: It’s very visually impressive,
it’s very big, it’s very futuristic.

As a scientist that’s the kind of place
that you feel like you should be working in.

Scott: That's John Williamson, a researcher
at the Crick who uses computers to study biochemical
dynamics in cell membranes.
Williamson: You have lots of different scientists with lots of different backgrounds all in

quite a close environment, so it’s really,
really good from that point of view.

Scott: That’s not to say other institutions
don’t foster multidisciplinary interactions,

but the Crick differs in the volume of opportunities
it offers researchers to mingle and collaborate,
explains postdoc Annick Sawala.

We caught up with Sawala in front of her exhibit
explaining how she studies differences in
disease risk between men and women.

Sawala: So the model that we use for that
is actually the fruit fly, drosophila.

We think that differences in both the regulation
of growth and also metabolism could help explain

some of the differences in disease risk that
we see in human diseases between males and females.

Scott: So you might be wondering, then, about
this image she chose to display.

It shows microscopic cells from underfed fruit
flies storing little spheres of fat.
Those are the tiny greenish orbs.

Human liver cells, it turns out, also store
fat like this during periods of starvation.

The stunning image is meant to convey a simple
idea.

Sawala: I think it’s interesting maybe for
the public to know that we can actually use

a really tiny and simple organism to study
quite complex processes,
such as metabolism, for example.

Scott: The British government spent around
700 million pounds—just under 900 million
US dollars—on the Crick Institute.

Now that the public can see what their money
bought, we asked them what they thought of
the investment.

Cornwall: The research they’re doing is
going to affect everyone.

They’re doing research into cancer and so
many other things.

700 million in the scheme of things is nothing
much at all so, yeah, money well spent.
Scott: Brilliant. Thank you very much indeed.
